Protect Your Business From Future Litigation

In a similar fashion, an attorney can help protect your business from future litigation by directing you towards business best practices and warning you about common legal problems.

While many people feel that retaining a small business attorney is an unnecessary expense, speaking with an attorney after you're already in a lawsuit is often too late.

A good lawyer can help you identify problems early on, and can provide actionable steps to help you avoid legal action in the future.

One of the best actions you can take when growing your business is building a working relationship with a local attorney.

If you're ever uncomfortable about a legal situation just give them a call for a quick consultation.

Better yet, look into local legal retainer services that can provide you with guidance on minor issues, such as document review and potential liability issues.

No matter what your path may be, protecting your company from potential litigation is a smart move.

The fact of the matter is simply that this is easier to do when you have an attorney in your contacts list.

Safely Scale Your Business For Future Growth

As with most things, business become more complicated as you add new services, products and people.

It can be difficult to scale your business safely in order to satisfy the future client needs, depending on your company's scope and range.

Similarly, the liabilities you take on as the owner can change over time as your company begins to serve more people and bring in more revenue.

An attorney for small businesses can ensure compliance wherever your company goes. They can also help you feel confident that your business is in line with federal, state and local laws.

What does a Business Lawyer do?

Legal counsel can assist individuals and organizations in all aspects of business law. Lawyers assist their clients in preparing legal documents, filing cases and overseeing hearings. They also help with settlements, depositions and sending correspondence. They can assist businesses in a variety of industries, including politics, real estate, criminal justice, and health care. Individuals and companies can benefit from the services of business lawyers:

  • Start a business

Start a business

  • Settle contract disputes

Settle contract disputes

  • Write contracts

Sign contracts

  • Navigate mergers and acquisitions

Navigate acquisitions and mergers

  • Deal with business issues and claims

Resolve business claims and issues

  • Property and real estate dispute resolution

Resolve property and real estate disputes

  • Control risk and ensure compliance

Control risk and ensure compliance

Related: Pros and Cons of Being a Lawyer

What is the best way to pay for a small business attorney?

Many small-business lawyers bill hourly rates. Once you decide what you need the lawyer for, check to see how much time the lawyer needs to complete your task. Lawyers desire to build strong relationships with clients. Lawyers may be open to negotiating a flexible fee schedule and payment plan. Some might even offer alternative fee arrangements (AFAs) or do work on a commission. Occasionally, lawyers may give free consultations to small business owners. You can ask your questions and gain a clear understanding of the advice that attorneys might give you.

Try not to make cost the main goal in hiring a small business lawyer. Often, the cheapest lawyers have the least experience. Although it may be tempting to choose the lowest-priced option, you might find yourself paying more. You may end up paying more over the long-term, even though it seems appealing. Either they aren't qualified or the hourly rate is higher.

Be clear with the lawyer about your expectations and budget before you hire them. Work out the fees, and then complete the standard fee agreement with the lawyer. This document states that you fill the attorney's retainer, which you should negotiate. A retainer is an agreement in which the owner of a small business pays an advance to cover the cost of money that will be needed today and for future work. This fund can be used by lawyers to help you with your legal matters.

Another option is a fixed price payment. Some lawyers charge a flat fee, no matter how long the task might take to finish.

Monthly retainers are another choice. This option is common for small businesses that want to use an experienced attorney to work closely with them for a time. This way one lawyer can understand every aspect of the business, and be able to resolve any issues that may arise. You and your lawyer can meet to discuss the completed work after six months or more have passed. This will allow both sides to renegotiate their monthly retainers.

Transactions, Business Formation and Governance

A great deal of litigation can be prevented if proper steps are taken on the front end regarding entity formation, commercial transactions and corporate governance. You can get a favorable outcome if you take care to safeguard your rights at the time your company was formed or the contract was written. The business law services we offer start at the time of company formation, and continue throughout the lifetime of the company. Count on the entity formation lawyers at MichieHamlett to help you understand the pros and cons of establishing your business as a corporation, partnership or hybrid entity such as an LLC or S corp. We'll help you set up your company as a registered legal entity licensed to do business in the state and make sure you start off with all the company documents, policies and agreements you need to get started.

As your business gets underway, our business transaction attorneys are here to negotiate, draft or review any contract or agreement, including employment contracts and independent contractor agreements, vendor and supplier contracts, asset purchases, lending and more. MichieHamlet can be a trusted resource for assistance with corporate governance matters, including drafting, interpreting, and reviewing buy-sell and vendor agreements, as well understanding correct voting procedures and compliance with securities regulations.

Business Lawyer Job Description Template

We are looking for an analytical Business Lawyer to be responsible for providing legal advice on our business matters, such as patents, contracts, labor agreements, regulatory measures, taxation, and intellectual property rights. This Business Lawyer is responsible for researching and developing corporate procedures.

A successful business lawyer should focus on the protection of company reputation and assets. You should be detail-oriented, knowledgeable, and persuasive, with excellent communication skills.

The Secretary of State

The Secretary of State can provide information on starting a business within your state. Most states have websites that offer detailed information about how to form and register a business in their area.

Some states also offer online legal resources such as templates for articles of incorporation or LLC formation documents, which you can use to get started. The National Association of Secretaries of State website allows you to search for and obtain contact information of the Secretary of State in your area.

Small businesses should also be aware of their state's laws and regulations, as well as any licenses or permits that may be required to operate in that area. This information can be found on the website of your state for the Secretary or you may contact the Small Business Development Center for help.

The Chamber Of Commerce in your area

Your local chamber of commerce is another place you could get legal advice for free. Many chambers offer members access to lawyers who can answer questions about specific legal issues affecting small businesses in their area, as well as other benefits.

You will need to join the chamber, just like your small business association. However, there are some chambers that offer free membership for entrepreneurs who are just starting out. You can find your local chamber of commerce by visiting the website of an organization like the United States Chamber of Commerce or contacting the nearest Small Business Development Center (SBDC) for help.

The benefits of becoming a business lawyer

The practical advantage is also that you can transfer the skills to a job with an agency or business. Many business lawyers become entrepreneurs, leaving behind the law practice but still retaining their legal knowledge.

If you look at the big picture, it is possible to have an important impact on economic engine performance. (As one business lawyer I know once said while working on a transaction, "I really like going to work each day. "I feel like a fish in the pond of commerce.

Business law is also much less combative than many other legal areas. The work does not involve disputes over something that has gone wrong, nor efforts to assign blame and responsibility for the wrong. It is important that there be lawyers to handle such matters, but the business lawyer is typically dealing with parties who all want the same thing. The bank lawyer's client wants to lend money, for example, because it is financially advantageous to do so, and the borrower wants to borrow the money because it will have a positive impact on the borrower's business. Both sides will work together to achieve the best possible deal. Negotiations can become contentious at times, but both parties are ultimately working towards a common goal.

Do I Really Need To Hire An Attorney?

Not all small business owners need to hire an attorney to stay protected.

Some may be able to get by with just the information found on Virginia's Business One Stop and other online resources.

Even if your entrepreneurial abilities are strong, you should consider hiring a lawyer as a first step.

It is important to assess the needs of your company and determine if hiring an attorney would be beneficial.

For example, if you're just operating as a sole proprietorship and selling jam at your local farmer's market, you probably don't need to speak with an attorney about your business.

However, if you want to expand your business across state lines (such as if you're selling products or services online), or if you want to form an LLC to protect yourself from personal liability, you may want to discuss your options with an attorney before you file any of the paperwork.

Put simply, the complexity of your business is directly proportional to your need for an attorney.

Your business will grow and you run the risk of financial and legal liability.

For this reason, it's usually wise to consult with an attorney before such problems appear, as hiring an attorney after you notice a problem will often be too little too late.

Do Startups Need A Business Lawyer?

There are many worries entrepreneurs have when they're beginning a business or are already running a small company. A business lawyer may be necessary. They may think they can't afford the high prices attorneys charge, since most small companies don't have additional capital to pay lawyers with. Many business owners will only employ a lawyer with experience in business law if their legal problems are serious.

It's a good idea to get legal help as soon as possible. This will save you time and make your business more profitable. While an attorney may not be necessary for every step in the business' life, it is better to have someone you can turn to if something goes wrong.

Business Law Websites

Nolo and FindLaw are websites that provide information on business law. They also offer many resources such as blogs, video posts and e-books. You can also search their databases to find an attorney that practices in a specific area of law so you're able to choose the right business lawyer for you. These websites also provide information on specific subjects such as employment law, intellectual property and small-business taxes.

For example, Nolo.com offers a free online course about the basics of business-related laws for small businesses, which you can take at your own pace or find out more by checking out their website.

FindLaw offers an online free course in legal issues and resources to entrepreneurs and small businesses. This one is geared specifically toward helping new business owners get started with their ventures and includes information like how to form an LLC or corporation, what kind of licenses and permits you need to run a business in your state, how to hire employees instead of contractors (and vice versa), etc.

Talk About Hiring, Firing, And Other Potential Liabilities

As the final and possibly most helpful service, attorneys can also act as useful resources in cases where you just need to talk about potential legal issues.

If you ever have a question about an aspect of your business (such as your hiring or firing practices), or if you need to deal with any other potential liabilities, an attorney can help keep you in check while also limiting the liability you take on in these processes.

Simply having someone to talk to is an often-overlooked benefit of having a lawyer on your side, and is certainly a resource you should take advantage of as you grow your new Virginia business.

Respectful Process

The law guarantees due process. This is grounded in the principles of fairness. It simply means that you give notice to the accused and allow them an opportunity to speak. For example, a person accused of a crime must be made aware of the charges and given the chance to plead a case. More broadly, one might say that we are all entitled to know the rules of the game--say, what actions are prohibited by law--and the chance to defend ourselves.

In business, I might translate the concept as notice and opportunity to perform. Many small businesses lack job descriptions, performance metrics or evaluation reviews. This causes confusion about the type of work employees should do and whether they are succeeding. Employers are often compelled to take action before it is too late, or keep underperformers on their team for too long. Employees may sense they are off track but remain unclear about how to course correct. Other employees are blindsided altogether when they are let go. This all leads to a loss of value for both the company and its employees.

Sometimes, the absence of procedure is deliberate. I have noticed founders fear that introducing procedure will bureaucratize the business, stifle entrepreneurship, and diminish the family culture. All of these fears are reasonable and, if not addressed properly, can have serious consequences. But I've also noticed that the refusal to introduce important procedure can be equally harmful: when people are unclear about their roles or performance, they are likelier to feel demotivated, disconnected, and confused. Importantly, what serves very small startups--agility and an "all hands on deck" mentality--can be counterproductive at scale when people need clarity and organization.

Use the principle of due process to inform your employees about their job expectations, as well as opportunities for improvement. While it doesn't have to be complicated, it should be a top priority. It will improve results, raise morale, and protect both the firm and the employees.

Asking For Referrals

Attorneys are often afraid to ask anything even if it is free marketing. What about a simple review of clients? No way, that's beneath them. Referrals? They don't need to beg for work.

The thing is, you know that you can provide superior services to anyone who is referred to your office. Asking for referrals isn't asking for charity. This is asking for help to human beings. And who better to help them than you?

Attorney referral agreements and services are an interesting concept that must be treated with caution. For example, when I was a regular divorce attorney, most divorce attorneys I knew had a QDRO attorney. For every divorce case, once they finished the settlement or trial and had a judgment in hand, they would refer all of their cases to the same QDRO attorney to process the retirement account division.

What is the ABA Model Rules for this? It depends. Rule 7.2 and its comments set forth the following:

  • Referrals are free (exception token presents)
  • There are no exclusive referral arrangements. Any referral agreement must be made known to the client.
  • Referral services and lead generation services are allowed, but they cannot vouch for a lawyer's quality. The services advertised must not be misleading.

Returning to the QDRO example, such a referral practice is allowed so long as the QDRO attorney does not pay for the referrals. If the referrals are reciprocal, it cannot be exclusive, and the client needs to be kept in the loop.

You will need to select a legal structure if you are looking to open a business in Virginia.

The default legal structure in Virginia is a sole proprietorship (or, if the business has multiple owners, a partnership).

Generally speaking, your business automatically becomes a sole proprietorship the moment you make your first sale, meaning that you must follow all relevant rules governing such businesses.

Due to the tax and liability issues that sole proprietorships can create, they are often frowned on in business.

For this reason, many small business owners choose to either start their business as a limited liability company (LLC), or convert their sole proprietorship into an LLC once it reaches a certain size.
